question: What kind of object in space typically contains hundreds of billions of stars and is located millions of light-years from Earth?

content.source_1: Large galaxies typically contain hundreds of billions of stars; for example, the Milky Way is estimated to host roughly 100–400 billion stars.
content.source_2: Many external galaxies lie tens of millions of light-years from Earth; an object about 30 million light-years away is a common distance scale for nearby galaxies.
content.source_3: The diameters of entire galaxies are generally tens to hundreds of thousands of light-years; even typical dwarf galaxies span at least a few thousand light-years, so a 500-light-year-wide object is far smaller than a whole galaxy.
content.source_4: Giant H II regions (massive star-forming nebulae) can span hundreds of light-years—for instance, the Tarantula Nebula is roughly 650–1000 light-years across—and such regions are routinely observed in galaxies tens of millions of light-years away.
content.source_5: Ultracompact dwarf galaxies exist with sizes of only a few hundred light-years across, overlapping the scale of large star clusters while still being classified as galaxies.
